reviewTitles: Honest review :An average read about the reality
reviewBody: This guy is famous from his youtube channel very few of them are good. Actually he knows what kind of language, style topics the Indian young audience likes so he prepared his material in the same way. The book's cover starts from a cliched line read-only if you are prepared to get your feelings hurt .btw let me tell I have read Rollo Tommasi all of the three books in rational male series, can't hurt me by David Goggin, Robert Sapolsky Behave: The Biology of Humans at Our Best and Worst, Brain, Nicholas Taleb, Robert green and may more psychology books where they explain anything backed with research, stats, facts. But Here1. No psychological study reference is given in this book why should we do that.2. The author tries to use unnecessary curse words to create an impact.3. He only gives a catchy name to the chapter and keeps explaining the same words in a different way. He doesn't explain the psychological cause and effect of something.4.wrong perception about pickup artists community and the rejection game.5.The author doesn't know that each person has a different experience ,u bringing,pyschology we all Learn and Improve by different methods.few laws or habits cannot be imposed on everyone.I can keep writing cons for the book the list keeps going on so in shortThe only positive point to the book is that it is a good start for teenagers for red pill awareness. For other people, i won't recommend it. You can better start with Robert green and Ryan holidays books

reviewTitles: Some good concepts but badly written
reviewBody: My first book of the year and i picked it up after seeing earlier good reviews. I had decided to finish reading in 1-2sittings but i took over 10 sittings. The writing style is so verbose, doesn't flow smoothly and vague at most places that reader loses interest. However, i did pick up some good learnings like rejection is normal, think about self as nation, admire people for their capabilities rather than blindly follow them etc.I have revisited earlier comments and it seems the reviewers were already a fan of author (referring to him as Sir) and hence rated book highly. But me as a first time reader of thos author's work, wasn't too impressed. I am glad this book is over!!!!

reviewTitles: Simple & Light Reading. May Disappoint - Dependent on Reader's Expectation.
reviewBody: The book does a decent job of relating the concept of Ikigai to modern day psychology (with Frankl's Logotherapy from Man's Search for Meaning among others) and a few scientific references in a simple manner. It talks about how purpose plays an important role in a man's life and the different ways in which it manifests itself. It also tackles some ways to 'find your flow' and ensure that what you do receives 100% of your attention and that you enjoy whatever you are creating.The book also discusses certain other Japanese concepts like takumi (specialized workers) and moai (connections with community or friend-circle). The brief discussions have the benefit of being to the point and simple but also pose the risk of trivializing them into regular self-help advice. The book also delves into Japanese perspectives on living life and persevering without getting caught up in artificially-created urgency. But again, maybe the authors wished for the readers to research more or meditate more on the content given the concise treatment of the same.The chapters on diet and exercises have more details and thus, may be more useful. Certain foods are dealt with in greater detail as is the concept of 'hara hachi bu' wherein one eats only 80% of what would actually assuage his hunger. The chapter on exercises includes illustrations and steps. While they may suffice for some of the purposes mentioned in the book - the philosophy behind them, progressive increments and other essential details are missing or insufficient.I was interested in the concept of Ikigai and wanted to read more about it. Despite being well-written and presenting modern applications, the book did not fulfill my requirements at all. Some of the condensed content made me think that the extended research, including on-site interviews, done by the authors for writing this book was clearly lost in translation or presentation in certain parts.The hardcover is pretty and soothing with its matte texture. Inner pages are smooth and heavy with a cream tinge. The font size is good. The spine as well as pages hold up well. Overall, the book is quite light and sturdy. Bought it for INR 460 against MRP of INR 499.

reviewTitles: The best book to read during your break time.
reviewBody: I personally believe that having a purpose on in life and then giving it your all is the most important to lead a happy life. This book validates so.Ikigai is a short but not very short book based on a Japanese concept. According to this concept, we find the deeply sown purpose of our lives from within ourselves by defining our passion, mission, vocation and profession. It gives you tips as to how the simplest things in our life, like sometimes, taking a pause, are what will give us a long and happy life.I bought a hardcover because of it’s extremely pretty cover. The cover itself will soothe your mind whenever you look at it. The title does go with the book but personally for me, not as I thought it would.If you are expecting it to help you find your Ikigai, give you step by step solution as to how you can find it and reward it with millions of dollars, you’ll be disappointed. This book is full of facts, real life experience from Japan’s Okinawa and compels you to focus more on you : your health, your choices, your focus and your inner happiness. It will probably be the only book you’ll come across that tells you to take it, relax, but also burn in your passion.The language is as simplistic and beautiful as the cover and it’s content. Not many tough words and very beginner-friendly in the reading world. The structure to is great with a prologue, 9 chapters, an epilogue and a list of more suggestions for you to explore in the end.Coming to the overall feel of the book, it’s very cozy. In it’s own way, it also does help you slightly to find your own Ikigai.I thought it would be a full on hustle kind of book but I felt relaxed after this read. I was ready to take on my tasks stress-free. Though it is not something extremely crazy and different, it definitely is a one-time read for all the hustlers or non-hustlers out there who think they have to punish themselves to get what they want.

The Japanese secrets to a long and happy life u can really find your ikigai it will show how to leave urgency behind,and find our purpose,nurture ,friendship and throw yourself to your passionIts my own rating no one paid or asked its just my OpinionI learnt something in every books I readIt has many information about many thingsTake a page ask yourself a question1)What u love2)what u are good at3)what the world needs4)what can u be paidWhat's your reason for beingWe should always challenge our brain that we think we can't do don't do many of things at once do one by oneFill new information every day to your brainDon't over stress little stress is needed or else we will be lazy be calmREAD LOTS OF BOOK 's....reread till u understandIf I wasted anyone's time sorry for thatHave a nice and happy stress free day a head there are many exercise that japense do daily at morningGood book😊Anyone can buy and read it is easy English

IkigaiThe Japanese Secret to a Long and Happy LifeBy Hector Garcia and Francesc MirallesI will be confessing by saying that i bought this book just because of its attractive cover, such a soothing color combination which itself calmed me.This book is all about finding your passion in life, your “ikigai” which will help you to live a happy, content, active and long life. It talks about art of staying young while growing old, about relaxing, about not running behind materialistic things, how to improve your performance in daily routine and to stay focused.One of the best lesson which I liked was how to be more anti fragile. It talked about creating more options, by devoting time in your passion, taking small risks for increasing your experience and to get rid of the things which makes us more fragile.Before reading this book I felt that there would be some manoeuvre to follow for finding your ikigai, but there is just overview of many therapies which left me little unsatisfied and disappointed. There were few things like proverbs, quotes and traditions from centritains which I found were not really required. There is no rocket science written in this book but some of the facts are eye opening.P. S . And seriously I wish I could learn sun salutation and other exercise by reading.Overall I will say it’s a easy, simple read for beginners for setting up small goals.Only staying active will make you want to live a hundred years.——-Japanese proverbBook starts with this proverb and this literally summarises the book.

This book is full of facts, real life experience from Japan’s Okinawa and compels you to focus more on you : your health, your choices, your focus and your inner happiness. It will probably be the only book you’ll come across that tells you to take it, relax, but also burn in your passion.The language is as simplistic and beautiful as the cover and it’s content. Not many tough words and very beginner-friendly in the reading world. The structure to is great with a prologue, 9 chapters, an epilogue and a list of more suggestions for you to explore in the end.Coming to the overall feel of the book, it’s very cozy. In it’s own way, it also does help you slightly to find your own Ikigai.I thought it would be a full on hustle kind of book but I felt relaxed after this read. I was ready to take on my tasks stress-free. Though it is not something extremely crazy and different, it definitely is a one-time read for all the hustlers or non-hustlers out there who think they have to punish themselves to get what they want.

reviewTitles: Simple & Light Reading. May Disappoint - Dependent on Reader's Expectation.
reviewBody: The book does a decent job of relating the concept of Ikigai to modern day psychology (with Frankl's Logotherapy from Man's Search for Meaning among others) and a few scientific references in a simple manner. It talks about how purpose plays an important role in a man's life and the different ways in which it manifests itself. It also tackles some ways to 'find your flow' and ensure that what you do receives 100% of your attention and that you enjoy whatever you are creating.The book also discusses certain other Japanese concepts like takumi (specialized workers) and moai (connections with community or friend-circle). The brief discussions have the benefit of being to the point and simple but also pose the risk of trivializing them into regular self-help advice. The book also delves into Japanese perspectives on living life and persevering without getting caught up in artificially-created urgency. But again, maybe the authors wished for the readers to research more or meditate more on the content given the concise treatment of the same.The chapters on diet and exercises have more details and thus, may be more useful. Certain foods are dealt with in greater detail as is the concept of 'hara hachi bu' wherein one eats only 80% of what would actually assuage his hunger. The chapter on exercises includes illustrations and steps. While they may suffice for some of the purposes mentioned in the book - the philosophy behind them, progressive increments and other essential details are missing or insufficient.I was interested in the concept of Ikigai and wanted to read more about it. Despite being well-written and presenting modern applications, the book did not fulfill my requirements at all. Some of the condensed content made me think that the extended research, including on-site interviews, done by the authors for writing this book was clearly lost in translation or presentation in certain parts.The hardcover is pretty and soothing with its matte texture. Inner pages are smooth and heavy with a cream tinge. The font size is good. The spine as well as pages hold up well. Overall, the book is quite light and sturdy. Bought it for INR 460 against MRP of INR 499.

reviewTitles: The idea of getting into the flow is very beautifully brought out giving contemporary examples.
reviewBody: The book talks of a number pointers picked up from different philosophies like stoicism while emphasising the need to get into the flow. It is not only about the longevity of the people of Okinawa but also how their lifestyles can be picked up to suit within the rush hour lifestyles of modern times.

reviewTitles: If you want a long, fulfilling life, get this book.
reviewBody: Ikigai - Book reviewA pure GEM. Short (1 hour to finish), massively impactful & UPLIFTING.Ikigai is a Japanese concept, which means “the happiness of always being busy". It explains the extraordinary longevity of the Japanese, especially on the island of Okinawa, wherethere are 24.55 people over the age of 100 for every 100,000 inhabitants!What I LOVED about the book is a reiteration of FACTS that we all know. Best ones:- Never RETIRE. (If you have recently retired parents who are grumpy & throw tantrums, give them this book)- Stop eating JUST when you are about to get full. “Hara hachi bu" means something like “Fill your belly to 80 percent.”- SLEEEEEP!!! Top models sleep a lot!- How to handle thoughts, emotions, BOREDOM. Vietnamese monk Thich Nhat Hanh, who would say, “Hello, solitude. How are you today? Come, sit with me, and I will care for you.”- A list of different Japanese meditations & practices.- The Pomodoro Technique to FOCUS : Get yourself a kitchen timer & commit to working on a single task as long as it’s running.If you want a long, fulfilling life, get this book.

reviewTitles: Easy read and calms your mind
reviewBody: Easy read. A few good rules stood out for me. For eg 80% rule on food and being stoic and imagining the worse daily to liberate yourselves of fears. There are plenty such as rules, you can choose what you like. The description of Japanese community that practices ikigai seemed simplistic and far cry from from the city life.The key question is finding your ikigai in this fast paced world. The book will give you hints, but ultimately you still need to find it yourselves. Anyway I give this book a sure thumbs up.

reviewTitles: The secret to lead an enjoyable long life
reviewBody: Excellent book highly recommended for the current generation that is filled with pressure, stress and anxiety.The book covers simple concepts and how we can implement it in our lives to lead a life of ease, joy and glory.

reviewTitles: Redesign your lifestyle for longevity and happiness
reviewBody: We all want to lead a long and healthy life. Don’t we? Ikigai has all the elements to decode it. Ikigai is a Japanese word, translates to “ the happiness of always being busy or engaged”. The people of Okinawa live a simple outdoor life, drink green tea, and eat a healthy diet served in a special bowl that limits to their eating. The book explains that every being has an Ikigai, a journey of self-discovery and it’s worth the search. Ikigai draws attention to the lifestyle of Japanese people showcasing how they lead an optimal healthy life, filled with happiness, and longevity. The main focus is on diet, daily activities and a sense of joy. It also includes wisdom from supercentenarians(above the age of 110) from all over the world.Every individual's Ikigai is different but the search is common. Still searching for you Ikigai, no worries, smile, take a long breath and find one. I’m all praises for this book and cannot stop gushing about it. Grab it today.

reviewTitles: A nice book but very basic
reviewBody: A nice book but very basic . For someone who has read alot of such books, it seemed slightly vague and generalized . Its a probably a good book to start your spiritual journey with.
I ordered two books but received only one and this was prepaid. Its fruad.

reviewTitles: Be Slow and Things would fall in Place
reviewBody: The title of the book suggests that it is unravelling The Japanese Secrets to a Long and Happy Life, but it also does incorporate the key elements from Indian way of life i.e.Yoga and the Chinese way of life i.e. Tai Chi. Indeed the key point that emerges from the book is that one should keep on moving and not spend most of the time of the day either sitting or lying down.It also dispels the notion that one should start withdrawing from the activities after one is officially retired and advocated that staying active is what would be the deciding factor if one aspires to complete a century on this planet- which incidentally is a Japanese quote from where the book starts. Does it not seem so pertinent in the times that we are living in- the Corona times. IKIGAI actually means living a meaningful life. Though Japan is a major rice growing country, the book advocates drawing from the patterns of food from people residing in Okinawa in Japan is that the food plate construct on a daily basis should be dominated by vegetables and Tofu, and there is a particular emphasis on the size of the plate. The plate should not be large, as we normally have in Indian conditions but it should be of medium size.However one may be hungry, one should aspire to eat 80% only which is called as Hara hachi bu in Japanese and were we to follow the maxim it would take care of quite a lot of health related issues that we are confronted with, associated with over eating.Interestingly enough Japanese have been practising the concept of saving called as Moai-where farmers get together to share best practices and also help one another with meager harvests. In the times of distress that the farming community is in the country, can we aspire to have such kind of a group of farmers. Farmers Producers Organizations have been formed but they need to converge to the concept of Moai to make it really effective.This group also had the provision of a monthly contribution akin the idea of SELF HELP GROUPS with a difference that the contribution is utilised for social activities and left over from the contribution is given a member based on his requirements.The book has tried to assimilate other such initiatives from around the world but the bottom line is that one has to find flow in everything that one is doing. There should not be any distraction or multi-tasking at all as it does not help anyway. To attain the flow, the authors have requested to adopt the policy of leaving the cell phones one hour before going to sleep, and one hour after getting up. Tough act to adopt? Each one of us has a passion inside us or the Ikigai and if we have found it we need to practice and fine tune it, and if not yet, it is incumbent upon us to discover it.NALIN RAI

This book is actually about 'how to have a long life', with particular reference to Ogimi, a rural town in the north of the island with a population of 3,000, called the Village of Longevity, that has the highest life expectancy in the world.The authors say that Ikigai is one of the keys to living long, the others being diet, exercise and strong social ties.Ikigai is all about finding your passion, focussing on it, and thereby realising your full potential.This is my first book on Ikigai, which I am hearing for the first time. It's a good introduction to it. The book gives 10 rules of Ikigai, based on conversations with the centenarians.

I read this book on somebody's recommendation. The book is about people living in an island called Ogimi in Japan where people are long lived and live a very healthy life. It basically tells us how these people have cultivated few habits which helps them to live a long, happy and healthy life. It involves few set of practices which are also linked to Japanese culture. How these people live a simple community based life where they enjoy doing small things and living happily together. It basically tells us how we can enjoy life by simply figuring out and doing what we enjoy ? Simple life based on enjoying your purpose of being, but all it takes to figure out first. ie to find one's ikigai.

reviewTitles: Average book with some golden nuggets
reviewBody: While i enjoyed reading the book, i felt that a lot of material is taken from other books by Victor Frankl, Mihaly C and other authors. Some chapters were brilliant but some just lacked quality content. Some pages have dedicated to teach the reader how to do excercises like Sun salutation etc, i found it to be completely useless as I can learn it from youtube rather than reading a book.I had higher expectations

reviewTitles: Vendor is a cheat, the book is not a hardcover.
reviewBody: This review is strictly about the vendor and not the content of the book. I was promised a hardcover, but it is just a thicker paper back. The paper quality and the print is pretty mediocre. I felt cheated. The ratings are for the vendor.

reviewTitles: Don’t judge this book by its cover 🤦🏻‍♀️
reviewBody: Beautiful cover, pointless book! What a waste. It’s got nothing that’s not obvious.

Ikigai came to me at a moment when I was feeling distracted and lost from my ultimate goal. Also, I really feel sad to see my 75 plus mom in law and 65 plus mom to see sticking to bed and complaining that they are good for nothing now. I don’t want to be one of these old women who can’t rejoice life anymore, I wish to have both mental and physical strength in my old age too that’s why I have entertained Yoga to my daily routine.The book starts with Japanese proverb “Only staying active will make you want to live a hundred years” and it touches the art of staying young while growing old and also shares antiaging secrets. It also recommends to find flow in everything you doand master longevity. It gives a comparison of logotherapy of psychotherapy and prefers the previous. Apart from that, the book also tells the experience tales of centenarians as how they made it upto living longer and healthier life. The diet and exercise carry an essential ingredient in a perfect recipe of life.“Nana Korobi Ya Oki/ Fall seven times, rise eight” is the key to remain antifragile and be resilient to deal with the setbacks. Follow the philosophies of Budhism and Stoicism which aim at practicing well being while you are enjoying life’s pleasures. According to stoicism, we should be able to control our emotions and curb our ego and negative emotions.I even loved the ‘wabi sabi’ and ‘ichi-go ichi-e’ concepts which tell us that instead of looking for beauty in perfection, we should look out beauty in the given things-the things that are incomplete and temporary.Although the content on Yoga is something I just skipped because these were known facts and considerations.On the whole, Ikigai is a beautiful gift to the society. It leads you from darkness to light and follow a right path to healthy lifestyle. Worry less, Walk an extra mile and Weigh your burdens less. A good diet and some sort of exercise is needed to be added. Above all, everyone must have some purpose in life. It is the reason to live ‘ikigai’ and not anything else, which keeps you going. The authors Hector Garcia and Francesc Miralles stress on never retire policy so as to stay young inside.

reviewTitles: An account of receiving beat tips for a long life
reviewBody: Excellent book giving a guideline on a healthy living along with achieving yours life goals. The book not only details the best practices of living a long life but also guides step by step towards achieving a purposeful life. It explains good practices to be followed along with a good diet and mental stamina to have a longer fulfilling life.

reviewTitles: The books in absolutely flawless condition, and the content ...
reviewBody: The books in absolutely flawless condition, and the content is well established, it's just a 4 hour read if you are UpTo it and trust me anybody will feel on moon for a while after you finish the book.

My test of a good book is the one that you finish in one go (of course after attending to mandatory routines like office or personal matters). The book gives a lot of practical insight into how to lead a very happy and meaningful life, both in terms of personal well being and professional satisfaction. It recommends a very simple recipe for physical, emotional and professional well being. It is bound to make a difference in terms of one’s approach to life. I would highly recommend this book for everyone.
A lovely book maybe one of those which changed my life.. Ikigai very well explains all the things needed to be a Centenarian !! Worth every penny ! I loved it

Finding a purpose to work which can make you jump out of the bed every morning - amazing concept ! The book is written in a simple and sophisticated way covering very minute details.Working with the same enthu and activeness every day even after 100 years of age is very inspiring .

It is not only about the longevity of the people of Okinawa but also how their lifestyles can be picked up to suit within the rush hour lifestyles of modern times.

reviewTitles: If you want a long, fulfilling life, get this book.
reviewBody: Ikigai - Book reviewA pure GEM. Short (1 hour to finish), massively impactful & UPLIFTING.Ikigai is a Japanese concept, which means “the happiness of always being busy". It explains the extraordinary longevity of the Japanese, especially on the island of Okinawa, wherethere are 24.55 people over the age of 100 for every 100,000 inhabitants!What I LOVED about the book is a reiteration of FACTS that we all know. Best ones:- Never RETIRE. (If you have recently retired parents who are grumpy & throw tantrums, give them this book)- Stop eating JUST when you are about to get full. “Hara hachi bu" means something like “Fill your belly to 80 percent.”- SLEEEEEP!!! Top models sleep a lot!- How to handle thoughts, emotions, BOREDOM. Vietnamese monk Thich Nhat Hanh, who would say, “Hello, solitude. How are you today? Come, sit with me, and I will care for you.”- A list of different Japanese meditations & practices.- The Pomodoro Technique to FOCUS : Get yourself a kitchen timer & commit to working on a single task as long as it’s running.If you want a long, fulfilling life, get this book.

reviewTitles: Easy read and calms your mind
reviewBody: Easy read. A few good rules stood out for me. For eg 80% rule on food and being stoic and imagining the worse daily to liberate yourselves of fears. There are plenty such as rules, you can choose what you like. The description of Japanese community that practices ikigai seemed simplistic and far cry from from the city life.The key question is finding your ikigai in this fast paced world. The book will give you hints, but ultimately you still need to find it yourselves. Anyway I give this book a sure thumbs up.

reviewTitles: The secret to lead an enjoyable long life
reviewBody: Excellent book highly recommended for the current generation that is filled with pressure, stress and anxiety.The book covers simple concepts and how we can implement it in our lives to lead a life of ease, joy and glory.

reviewTitles: Redesign your lifestyle for longevity and happiness
reviewBody: We all want to lead a long and healthy life. Don’t we? Ikigai has all the elements to decode it. Ikigai is a Japanese word, translates to “ the happiness of always being busy or engaged”. The people of Okinawa live a simple outdoor life, drink green tea, and eat a healthy diet served in a special bowl that limits to their eating. The book explains that every being has an Ikigai, a journey of self-discovery and it’s worth the search. Ikigai draws attention to the lifestyle of Japanese people showcasing how they lead an optimal healthy life, filled with happiness, and longevity. The main focus is on diet, daily activities and a sense of joy. It also includes wisdom from supercentenarians(above the age of 110) from all over the world.Every individual's Ikigai is different but the search is common. Still searching for you Ikigai, no worries, smile, take a long breath and find one. I’m all praises for this book and cannot stop gushing about it. Grab it today.

reviewTitles: Be Slow and Things would fall in Place
reviewBody: The title of the book suggests that it is unravelling The Japanese Secrets to a Long and Happy Life, but it also does incorporate the key elements from Indian way of life i.e.Yoga and the Chinese way of life i.e. Tai Chi. Indeed the key point that emerges from the book is that one should keep on moving and not spend most of the time of the day either sitting or lying down.It also dispels the notion that one should start withdrawing from the activities after one is officially retired and advocated that staying active is what would be the deciding factor if one aspires to complete a century on this planet- which incidentally is a Japanese quote from where the book starts. Does it not seem so pertinent in the times that we are living in- the Corona times. IKIGAI actually means living a meaningful life. Though Japan is a major rice growing country, the book advocates drawing from the patterns of food from people residing in Okinawa in Japan is that the food plate construct on a daily basis should be dominated by vegetables and Tofu, and there is a particular emphasis on the size of the plate. The plate should not be large, as we normally have in Indian conditions but it should be of medium size.However one may be hungry, one should aspire to eat 80% only which is called as Hara hachi bu in Japanese and were we to follow the maxim it would take care of quite a lot of health related issues that we are confronted with, associated with over eating.Interestingly enough Japanese have been practising the concept of saving called as Moai-where farmers get together to share best practices and also help one another with meager harvests. In the times of distress that the farming community is in the country, can we aspire to have such kind of a group of farmers. Farmers Producers Organizations have been formed but they need to converge to the concept of Moai to make it really effective.This group also had the provision of a monthly contribution akin the idea of SELF HELP GROUPS with a difference that the contribution is utilised for social activities and left over from the contribution is given a member based on his requirements.The book has tried to assimilate other such initiatives from around the world but the bottom line is that one has to find flow in everything that one is doing. There should not be any distraction or multi-tasking at all as it does not help anyway. To attain the flow, the authors have requested to adopt the policy of leaving the cell phones one hour before going to sleep, and one hour after getting up. Tough act to adopt? Each one of us has a passion inside us or the Ikigai and if we have found it we need to practice and fine tune it, and if not yet, it is incumbent upon us to discover it.NALIN RAI

This book is actually about 'how to have a long life', with particular reference to Ogimi, a rural town in the north of the island with a population of 3,000, called the Village of Longevity, that has the highest life expectancy in the world.The authors say that Ikigai is one of the keys to living long, the others being diet, exercise and strong social ties.Ikigai is all about finding your passion, focussing on it, and thereby realising your full potential.This is my first book on Ikigai, which I am hearing for the first time. It's a good introduction to it. The book gives 10 rules of Ikigai, based on conversations with the centenarians.

I read this book on somebody's recommendation. The book is about people living in an island called Ogimi in Japan where people are long lived and live a very healthy life. It basically tells us how these people have cultivated few habits which helps them to live a long, happy and healthy life. It involves few set of practices which are also linked to Japanese culture. How these people live a simple community based life where they enjoy doing small things and living happily together. It basically tells us how we can enjoy life by simply figuring out and doing what we enjoy ? Simple life based on enjoying your purpose of being, but all it takes to figure out first. ie to find one's ikigai.

Ikigai came to me at a moment when I was feeling distracted and lost from my ultimate goal. Also, I really feel sad to see my 75 plus mom in law and 65 plus mom to see sticking to bed and complaining that they are good for nothing now. I don’t want to be one of these old women who can’t rejoice life anymore, I wish to have both mental and physical strength in my old age too that’s why I have entertained Yoga to my daily routine.The book starts with Japanese proverb “Only staying active will make you want to live a hundred years” and it touches the art of staying young while growing old and also shares antiaging secrets. It also recommends to find flow in everything you doand master longevity. It gives a comparison of logotherapy of psychotherapy and prefers the previous. Apart from that, the book also tells the experience tales of centenarians as how they made it upto living longer and healthier life. The diet and exercise carry an essential ingredient in a perfect recipe of life.“Nana Korobi Ya Oki/ Fall seven times, rise eight” is the key to remain antifragile and be resilient to deal with the setbacks. Follow the philosophies of Budhism and Stoicism which aim at practicing well being while you are enjoying life’s pleasures. According to stoicism, we should be able to control our emotions and curb our ego and negative emotions.I even loved the ‘wabi sabi’ and ‘ichi-go ichi-e’ concepts which tell us that instead of looking for beauty in perfection, we should look out beauty in the given things-the things that are incomplete and temporary.Although the content on Yoga is something I just skipped because these were known facts and considerations.On the whole, Ikigai is a beautiful gift to the society. It leads you from darkness to light and follow a right path to healthy lifestyle. Worry less, Walk an extra mile and Weigh your burdens less. A good diet and some sort of exercise is needed to be added. Above all, everyone must have some purpose in life. It is the reason to live ‘ikigai’ and not anything else, which keeps you going. The authors Hector Garcia and Francesc Miralles stress on never retire policy so as to stay young inside.

Name- The SpyWritten By- Paulo CoelhoPublished by- Penguin BooksPages- 186Ratings- ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️(✨💫💫)/5 (4.7/5)Plot-Penned down by the famous author of The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, The Spy is the story of the famous Margaretha Zelle popularly known as Mata Hari. Her lifestyle, her friend circle everything came to scrutiny during the First world war, where France labelled her as A Spy and a double agent for both France & Germany. Was she really a spy? or just a free thinking independent woman who was made a scapegoat during the most dreaded war? (Read the book to find out)Review-->Positive points-●The author divide the book in 3 parts. The first 2 parts were in Mata Hari's own voice through her letters to her lawyer Mr. Clunet & the 3rd was in Mr. Clunet's own letters written for Mata Hari, a tricky concept which worked for this book.●The story portrays brilliantly all the stages of Mata Hari's entire life from her childhood days in Holland to her first days in France when she was at the height of her succes and then also her last days when her name was demolished publicly.● It captures her love towards France, the very country which denied her very innocence, her so-called friends who deserted her in her need.●The conception of love that Mata Hari coveted was so different yet honest but ultimately she couldn't understand the love of Mr. Clunet whom she accused of fighting her case half heartedly was heartbreaking.->Negative points-◆The only one I could find was the story felt rushed sometimes, there were some gaps which if filled would have resulted in something as a perfect creation.Recommendation-I would urge every to read this book. The story is not just Mata Hari's but all the strong willed women feared by a society which is dominated by men.

The SpyAuthor- Paulo CoelhoPublisher- Penguin IndiaGenre- Fiction(Self-help)Pages- 186My Rating- 3.6/5🌟Have u heard of Mata Hari? And if u don't know her then please google it🤔. Her only fault was to be an independent woman. And that she was born in the wrong time.💃'The Spy' by Paulo Coelho is the memoir of Mata Hari and her struggles and experience in her self- awakening. The way she dealt with all her life problems with courage and never gave up. From dealing with her mother's death at a young age to being born at a small town to being raped at the age of 16 years by her school principal to living her days begging for the company of a man to fill her empty days and nights to dealing with the death of her baby boy who was killed by his nanny. When she arrived in Paris, she had no money nor any wardrobe and later started ruling Paris. She has been the fascination of men and the envy of women. And she started performing as a Dutch exotic dancer and courtesan. She got an offer from the German Ministry of Foreign affairs. She was unaware that her life was about to change all of a sudden.🙊💃She was punished for Espionage and for being a spy for Germany during the World War I. What had led her to this? And then as a war prisoner, her mercy petition was also rejected and she was killed by Firing Squad in France.💃My Review-This is the fifth book that I read of Paulo Coelho. This book will give you the feel of Paulo Coelho and his writing style. Though I felt that this does not occupy my best top 3 reads of Paulo Coelho because of being a biographical one and there were some places where I felt there were a lot of loose ends in the story.

The book was very gripping from the very beginning. Mata Hari's story, written in the form of a letter brings out the human side of a very tragic end. The pictures were a nice touch as well. However, this book must not be treated as a comprehensive coverage of Mata Hari's life. It leaves a lot of unanswered questions which would pique your interest for sure.

First of all I am very satisfied with the quality of the of the book the print , the binding etc .My second Paulo Coelho book after the Alchemist . Although I am a guy who loves reading long books . This is a very short one and I finished it in 3-4 days . The story is very gripping eventhough I already am aware of Mata Hari's story . The narration style was brilliant when her initial struggles are potrayed and in the end I felt really sad for the fate of a woman who just wanted to be independent .I would highly recommend the reader to buy this book. The English is also simple enough . A story of struggle , success , love and despair

reviewTitles: It is based on the story of Margaretha Geertruida better known by the stage name Mata Hari and The ...
reviewBody: Paulo Coelho is one of those writers who take you deep into His characters and you can feel connected to those characters until last page of the book.The spy is one of such Novel , It is based on the story of Margaretha Geertruida better known by the stage name Mata Hari and The whole story is told in Her voice through her final letters , She arrived in Paris she was penniless. Within a months she was the most celebrated women in the city.During 1917 when the whole country was consumed in Paranoia, Mata Hari's lifestyle brought her under suspicion, She was arrested and charged of espionage and finally executed by firing squad in the France.The spy is the unforgettable story of woman who dared to defy convention and paid the ultimate price.

reviewTitles: Brilliant masterpiece from Paul coelho based on a true story

I own last three versions of this book.Every time an update is made one should have it to stay up-to-date with latest data/facts along with old data, because the exam patterns are changing with time.Laxmikant of Polity is a must have for a Civil service aspirant.This update has added 6 new chapters :1. Goods and services tax Council.2. National Commission for backward classes.3. National Investigation Agency.4. National disaster management authority.5. Role of Regional parties.6. Coalition government.Apart from the above addition, there are added items to various chapters.This is latest (2020) version of this book.I ordered this on Great Indian Sale, got some discount.Amazon delivery was awesome.I have uploaded contents of the book. I hope it will help new buyers.Study well and Repeat. It's a massive book.Cheers to all hard working aspirants.Thank you.

I already had hard copy of older version. This time for latest version I opt for kindle version.Book is excellent. As compared to my 4th version (read by my sister) this is highly updated and recommended to all.As for kindle version, advantage is that I can read on my kindle reader(which I don't have) PC or mobile. With mobile I can read any where and when ever I want. This e-book have 'word wise' option which make easy to understand difficult words without referring to dictionary, very helpful to those who have weak English. Dictionary is available in many language including Hindi.Disadvantages is that I cannot lend this book to anyone without sharing my Amazon user name and password. Text to speech is only possible with Alexa devices(android app available for mobile) or other kindle product such as Fire HDX, Kindle Fire HD, Kindle Fire, Amazon Echo, Amazon Tap etc.Text to speech with Alexa(mobile app) is very clear and easy understanding but difficult point it from where to read.

reviewTitles: Spectrum Modern India By Rajiv Ahir
reviewBody: Got this book at Rs.315.1. First of Original book. No xerox copy provided by the seller. as there is a hologram at the top of the title page & also a Amazon Prime product.2. Dimension of the book is small. You can easily carry it to any place. But don't go with it's size. it is a world of information about the past of India.3. Page are good in quality. No. of Pages 848 main topics & 32 pg. (content, title page etc.).4. Appendices at the back are really good for quick revision before exam.5. Topics are well arranged.#But one think of this book I'll never accept that is it's language and it's criticisms about the work of our great revolutionary leaders. One cannot use the word "Militant Nationalism" to define the work of our great leaders. It hurts the sentiment of crores of Indian. Except this the book is awesome. Go for it guys and get ready for your exams. Thanks Amazon.

reviewTitles: Best book for studying Modern India
reviewBody: The size of book is quite small and the packaging was excellent

Pros-1-Compact size.Looks good in the bookshelf and feels adorable in lap.2-Font size is okay-okay,you can't complain text is too small to read.3-cover is strong and shiny and doesn't disappoint as a paperback book.Cons-1-Too much margin on the outer side of paper and less margin on the side of gluing makes it a little difficult to read,they should've done the margining vice versa.2-Ink starts a little wearing off when you touch it but it's not going to disappear or ruin the content.3-Paper and ink used for printing is of average quality.Overall, if you have no problem in getting it bound with a hardcover and don't have a habit to interact with writing, it's a good product.
